mw_today: Mostly sunny, with a high near 47. South wind 5 to 10 mph.
mw_tonight: Isolated snow showers after 3am.  Mostly cloudy, with a low around 27. South wind 8 to 10 mph.  Chance of precipitation is 20%.
btac_hazard:
Spring warm up continues today, with above freezing temperatures expected from the valley floor to the highest peaks. Clouds could gradually increase throughout the day as a moisture starved short-wave trough begins to impact the area tonight. These clouds could mitigate some wet loose development at the lower elevations but there is some uncertainty surrounding this situation. Wind slabs are prevalent in the alpine and their sensitivity to triggers could increase with solar input.

Recent avalanche activity was observed in Avalanche Canyon yesterday, mostly wind slabs that were size 1.5 or less. 

Have left the 3/20 and 3/29 persistent slab problems in place for now, but sensitivity is expected to go down after the peak heating today and subsequent refreeze tonight. Clouds should mitigate some solar impacts tomorrow, and then we are back into full on high pressure with seasonal to above average temperatures. Looking at the long term forecast it's not looking very snowy for April right now, but that could obviously change.
btac_weatherdisc:
Yesterday and Last Night: Yesterday was mostly sunny and cool. Last night was clear and cold. Temperatures currently range from the low teens to low 20s throughout the forecast zones.

Today: Today will be mostly sunny with gradually increasing cloud cover throughout the day. High temperatures will reach the mid 30s on the peaks and mid 40s in the valleys. Ridgeline winds will be southerly in the 10-20 mph range.
btac_bottomline: Human triggered avalanches remain possible today, especially in steep, rocky, wind exposed areas at the middle and upper elevations. Buried crust-facet combinations lurk on NE through E through S slopes, though their strength should improve after today's warm up and refreeze. Moniter the effects of the sun on the snow surface today and minimize exposure time on steep sunlit slopes.
legecast: Bruce Springskiing will be out in full force today at Jackson Hole Mountain Resort. No snow to report in the past 24hrs but at just 6" shy of a 600" total for the season, there's plenty of goods to go around. The high pressure system that's kicking around will bring mainly dry weather through the daylight hours today accompanied by light to moderate winds. Temps are going to feel positively tropical mountain wide and should make for some exceptional warm weather shredding conditions. That's it for me this season! Thanks for a great one and we'll see you next November! -Orion
gt_detail:
2&quot of new snow overnight, 2&quot in the past 24 hours. 
Temperatures are beginning to warm up as we head towards the weekend. Expect patchy clouds today with moments of sunshine. There are still patches of good snow throughout the mountain if you know where to look. Come and get it before the warm spell arrives!
Sierra_weatherdisc: Some cold air pooled in the valleys overnight, and a few sensors still reported overnight lows in the single digits in those areas. Most of them show warmer temperatures than yesterday morning. The warming trend should continue today, with daytime highs climbing into the upper 30s to mid-40s above 7000 ft. Expect sunny skies for most of today. Some cloud cover may build over the region later this afternoon ahead of a small storm expected to arrive tonight. In addition to the increased cloud cover, this storm will bring a few inches of snow and strong SW winds to the area through tomorrow. Snow levels should hover around 6500 ft during the day tomorrow. Warmer, drier weather will return over the weekend.
Sierra_btmline: Sun and warm weather today could cause wet snow to slide downhill, weaken cornices, and make it easier to trigger slab avalanches where piles of wind-blown snow linger. Small areas of newly wind-drifted snow may start to form at higher elevations as the winds increase this afternoon. Watch for changing conditions to inform your travel plans and make plans to avoid being under cornices today.
Sierra_hazard_disc:
• Cornice pieces dropped on a sunny SE-facing test slope did produce small wind-slab failure mixed with a sluff of wet snow. Snowpit tests and ski cuts on other wind-loaded test slopes did not produce unstable results. Most of the sunny days in March have seen human-triggered wind slabs, and several close calls have occurred this spring.
  • Some rollerballs and pinwheels occurred around rocks and cliffs yesterday, but no larger wet loose avalanches were reported.
  • Massive cornices exist along many ridgelines. Some of them have deep cracks behind them. 
  • Surface hoar existed in many open areas yesterday morning, but it had started to melt and flatten due to daytime warming by yesterday afternoon.
  • Areas of soft cold snow still existed on some N-facing slopes yesterday.
UT_btmline: Today will be a shock to the snowpack as this will be the first real day of strong sunshine. Wet avalanches are likely on south and west facing slopes where the avalanche danger will rise to CONSIDERABLE.Even though there is barely a breath of wind this morning, I still wouldn't trust wind loaded slopes at upper elevations which also have a CONSIDERABLE danger.North and east facing slopes should have dry snow today and a MODERATE avalanche danger for soft slab avalanches in the new snow.With so much snow watch out for roof avalanches especially as the day heats up.
UT_avyconditions: This morning temperatures are hovering near 0 degrees F and winds are barely moving. Yesterday most areas received a trace to 2 inches of snow.Today will have clear skies and strong sunshine and light winds. Air temperatures will climb into the mid 20s F, but it will feel a lot warmer with light wind and plentiful sunshine.On south aspects and at low elevations, there should be an ice crust on top of the snow this morning. Mid and upper elevation northerly facing slopes should have great dry powder.
UT_recentactivity: There was plenty of avalanche activity this week, and UDOT is still digging through avalanche debris in Little Cottonwood Canyon. Generally, all the avalanches seemed to have been confined to the new snow. These slides ranged from massive ones in LCC to smaller ones like this one along the Mill Creek Road and this one in the foothills of Mt Olympus. Nikki skied on Mt Aire yesterday and found avalanches that happened during the storm and more recent ones. Photo of one of many large slides in LCC (UDOT)Check out all observations HERE.
solitude_detail: Dare we say it’s starting to feel like spring up here? After a very wintery start of the week, and a snowverwhelming Wednesday during which the canyon closed, we are now looking at several days of temperatures above freezing, along with quite a bit of sunshine. Today we expect partly cloudy skies and a high of around 37 — time to put away your powder shell (at least for now) and put on some sunscreen. The snow from recent storms has started to settle, but it’s still very playful out there. For a fun lap, dig your edges into Sunshine Bowl when the morning crunch begins to soften. What’s all that activity taking place at the base of Apex Express? We’re not building a swimming pool for the summer season —  it’s our mountain ops team prepping the hill for Saturday’s Pond Skim Beach Party. Check out our events calendar for details.
